title: reference request - Are finite projective planes isomorphic to PG(2,q), where q=p^k with p a prime?
body: I can't find any reference to the following question: Are finite projective planes isomorphic to $PG(2,q)$, where $q=p^k$ with $p$ a prime? I think it's meaningless to continue studying without reading and understanding this result. I think Hilbert was the first to demonstrate this, but I can't find a reference. Can anyone help me in this matter? Thanks! reference-request plane-geometry Share Cite Improve this question Follow edited Jul 27, 2019 at 0:33 ssx 2,898 3 3 gold badges 16 16 silver badges 37 37 bronze badges asked Jun 17, 2012 at 20:34 Frederick Silva 1 $\endgroup$ 7 6 $\begingroup$ It's not true, you must have wrong information. You can start here: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Non-Desarguesian_plane $\endgroup$ Felipe Voloch –  Felipe Voloch 2012-06-17 20:43:06 +00:00 Commented Jun 17, 2012 at 20:43 3 $\begingroup$ it isn't true... there are non-Desarguesian projective planes with 91 points and 91 lines. $\endgroup$ zeb –  zeb 2012-06-17 20:43:45 +00:00 Commented Jun 17, 2012 at 20:43 1 $\begingroup$ See also en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Projective_plane#Finite_projective_planes . $\endgroup$ Qiaochu Yuan –  Qiaochu Yuan 2012-06-17 23:36:29 +00:00 Commented Jun 17, 2012 at 23:36 2 $\begingroup$ Well, it is true for certain $q=p^k$, such as $q<=8$. I'd bet my boots it is also true for $k=1$ but this is a huge unsolved problem, not a literature search. $\endgroup$ Gordon Royle –  Gordon Royle 2012-06-18 02:09:50 +00:00 Commented Jun 18, 2012 at 2:09 2 $\begingroup$ @Felipe I'm not sure why it needs that assumption; the first part is true because for $q \leq 8$ we know everything and only Desarguesian planes exist. For $k=1$, I was referring to the fact that it is widely conjectured that projective planes of prime order are desarguesian which is independent of whether planes of non-prime- power order exist. $\endgroup$ Gordon Royle –  Gordon Royle 2012-06-18 06:10:43 +00:00 Commented Jun 18, 2012 at 6:10  |  Show 2 more comments 0 Sorted by: Reset to default Highest score (default) Date modified (newest first) Date created (oldest first) You must log in to answer this question.
